What is the sum of the smallest and second-smallest positive integers $a$ satisfying the congruence $$27a\equiv 17 \pmod{40}~?$$
inference:
We want to find the smallest and second-smallest positive integers $a$ that satisfy the congruence $27a \equiv 17 \pmod{40}$.
We need to find the modular inverse of 27 modulo 40.
$27 \times 3 = 81 \equiv 1 \pmod{40}$, so $27^{-1} \equiv 3 \pmod{40}$.
Multiplying both sides of the congruence $27a \equiv 17 \pmod{40}$ by 3, we get
$a \equiv 17 \times 3 \equiv 51 \equiv 11 \pmod{40}$.
Thus, the solutions are $a = 11 + 40k$ for integers $k$.
The smallest positive integer solution is $a = 11$ when $k = 0$.
The second smallest positive integer solution is $a = 11 + 40(1) = 51$ when $k = 1$.
The sum of the smallest and second-smallest solutions is $11 + 51 = 62$.
Final Answer: $\boxed{62}$ I hope it is correct.
